> Database dependent: normally inserting data into a database if pretty
> simple but it's true that if you plan to support Sybase, Oracle and
> mySQL, you may have to write 3 different scripts to populate your 3
> different databases.  But it must be done only once.

It is definitely true that each system has major variations, and finding
the common subset is problematic.  I've approached this problem a couple of
different ways.   

The first way is to assume that you'll need to be able to insert data into
any table that your application is using.  If this is the case, then you
can write the insertion code and tests for it up front, and then use the
actual insertion code to do the inserts.  The problem with this approach is
that to do any decent testing, you also need the retrieval code
(i.e. queries.)  And then you also need to be able to delete the data that
you've inserted if you want to leave the DB in a "pristine" state.  (So
you've have to insert the data, do your tests, and delete the data for each
test that needs the data, or in "setup" and "teardown" at the very least.)
In a project I'm currently working on, I've ended up with
"testInsertUpdateDelete<Object>" since you wind up testing all of these
functions if you want to test one of them.

Another case is where you don't ever need to insert any data - you're
accessing the DB in a read-only fashion.  In this case, hopefully you've
got access to test data in some form and you can write tests against the
real data.  If not, and you want to shortcut writing JDBC insertion code,
ant has a cool facility:
 <target name="generateTestData">
 <sql
    driver="COM.ibm.db2.jdbc.app.DB2Driver"
    url="jdbc:db2:<DB NAME>"
    userid="<usrname>"
    password="<password>"
    print="true"
    autocommit="true"
    >
  <classpath>
     <pathelement location="d:/sqllib/java/db2java.zip"/>
  </classpath>
      insert into someSchema.someTable ( column1, column2 ) 
          values ( 'value1' , 'value2' );
  </sql>
  </target>

You can throw "arbitrary" SQL into here and populate the database with test
data fairly easily.

Hope this is helpful!

Later,
	Dale
